However you also don't want to cherry pick your data to reach a conclusion (such as the data falls into a certain range). I think reframing it in terms of the position of the center of the quadratic (which is exactly the midpoint of the roots) and the distance between the said center and the roots is a much more intuitive way to put it, which is why I loved the video so much. In fact, it even holds for higher-dimensional quadratics and gives a useful picture of what is the set of roots of a quadratic.
So like if you're working in R^n with some inner product < , > (think the usual vector dot product for example), you can have quadratics of the form f(x) = <x, x> + <u, x> + C, where u is a constant vector in R^n and C a real constant.
Let m = -u/2, then you can factor f(x) = <x, x> + 2 <u/2, x> + <u/2, u/2> - ( <u/2, u/2> - C) = <x-m, x-m> - (<m,m> - C)
Setting f(x) = 0, we find <x-m, x-m > = <m, m> - C, or equivalently || x-m || = sqrt( ||m||^2 - C ) where || . || : y -> sqrt(<y, y>) is the euclidian norm associated with the inner product < , >.
So, in fact, you get the same answer: x is any point on the sphere of center m and radius sqrt(||m||^2 - C) -- aka, midpoint + radius in any direction, just like in the 1d case! You could for instance write that x = m + v * sqrt( ||m||^2 - C) where v is any unit vector (which means ||v|| = 1).

This tells us that finding the roots of a quadratic speaks in fact of a sphere more than a parabola! :D

PS : of course, I'm glossing over the cases where there are only 1 root or no R^n valued roots, but I'm sure other people can find nice geometric meaning to those as well ;-)

The formula tought in German schools is basically equivalent, but just derived differently:
In Germany it´s x = -p/2 ± sqrt((p/2)^2 - q) where p = b/a = b' and q = c/a = c'.
So it´s the same as midpoint ± distance = r,s (as seen in the video)
It´s derived like this:

ax^2 + bx + c = 0 | divide by a (b/a = p ; c/a = q)
x^2 + px + q = 0 | -q
x^2 + px = -q | adding (p/2)^2 to complete the binomial formula
x^2 + px + (p/2)^2 = (p/2)^2 - q | rewrite with the binomial formula
(x+(p/2))^2 = (p/2)^2 -q | take the root
x + (p/2) = ± sqrt((p/2)^2 - q) | - (p/2)
x = - (p/2) ± sqrt((p/2)^2 - q)
In Sweden we are taught the solution to x^2 + px + q = 0 instead, with the solution x = -p /2  ±  √((p/2)^2-q), which is known as the pq-formula.

Here's an interesting way to interpret. Let the turning point of a quadratic f(x)=ax^2+bx+c be (p,q). Then f(p+/-t)=q+at^2 for any real t. This is easy to show with a little algebra.

We can then let p-t=r, p+t=s, and immediately see at^2=-q gives t=sqrt(-q/a).

From this, we that r=p-sqrt(-q/a), and s=p+sqrt(-q/a). This is an easier way to read off the quadratic formula.

For example, solving x^2+6x+7=0, p=-6/2=-3, q=f(-3)=-2. Then r,s=-3+/-sqrt(2/1)=-3+/- sqrt(2)
